fields.Title of Contribution: Spatial dynamics of pathogen transmission in emergent vectors with explicit host interactions
fields.Journal: Physical Review E (Statistical, Nonlinear, and Soft Matter Physics) or PLoS One
fields.Description/Abstract:
Although the classical theories commonly used for the transmission dynamics of
vector-borne infections such as malaria, dengue and West Nile virus overlook
spatial heterogeneities, the distributions of larval habitat, potential hosts,
and the density and flight pattterns of the vectors all strongly influence
their transmission. Each of these creates a highly irregular spatiotemporal
patchwork through which pathogens may conduct, propelled forward by a mobile
vector sequentially acquiring, harboring, and creating new infections.
To investigate these dynamics in a simple setting, a single
cohort of locally-emergent vectors is considered. Emergent mosquitoes disperse
to encounter available hosts in their proximity, some of which are assumed to
harbor transmissible pathogens, and they are formulated to have contact
interactions, or bloodmeals, with these hosts for potential transmission
events. A spatial, probabilistic formalism for transmission is developed,
extending the classical theory, and it is applied to a case of simple host
dynamics: hosts are regarded as stationary and universally available to focus
on the infectious dynamics of primarily endophagic vectors. A latency prior to
infectiousness in the vector is included and the mosquito population feeds and
perishes according to classic malarial models. The infectious portion of the
vector population is compared with other sub-cohorts of the emergence,
including the fed and infected populations, and found to consist of
longer-lived mosquitoes that explore an extended region of space about the
larval source where they may infect distal hosts. The transmission formalism
is developed as a continuous space and real-time model carried out in
two-dimensions, and it unites classical Ross/Macdonald dynamics with a
reaction/diffusion approach. Connections to classical malarial epidemiology are
made throughout to emphasize the role of the included mosquito dispersal.
